questions.text: A patient is on propranolol for prophylaxis of atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs should not be given to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Verapamil

Highyeild:

Verapamil and diltiazem should be avoided with beta-blockers because both cause myocardial depression leading to marked depression of the myocardium. Also, additive sinus depression, conduction defects, or asystole may occur. i.v. Verapamil carries the risk of marked bradycardia, A-V block, cardiac arrest, and hypotension. It should not be used if PSVT is accompanied by hypotension or CHF and in patients who have received beta-blockers.

questions.text: Among the following options, Nitric oxide acts by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased c GMP

Highyeild:

Mechanism of Nitric oxide (NO): NO activates the soluble isoform of guanylyl cyclase Activated guanylyl cyclase increases intracellular levels of cyclic GMP Increased cyclic GMP promotes the dephosphorylation of the myosin light chain, and there is a reduction of cystolic Ca2+, leading to the relaxation of smooth muscle cells in a broad range of tissues. The NO-dependent relaxation of vascular smooth muscle leads to vasodilation. NO-mediated guanylyl cyclase activation inhibits platelet aggregation and relaxes the smooth muscle in the bronchi and GI tract.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. c GMP: is a cyclic nucleotide derived from guanosine triphosphate (GTP). cGMP acts as a second messenger, much like cyclic AMP. Its most likely mechanism of action is the activation of intracellular protein kinases in response to the binding of membrane-impermeable peptides. Option: D. c AMP: is a second messenger, or cellular signal occurring within cells, that is important in many biological processes. cAMP is a derivative of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and used for intracellular signal transduction in many different organisms, conveying the cAMP-dependent pathway.

questions.text: All the following are uses of Verapamil except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sick sinus syndrome

Highyeild:

Verapamil is used in hypertension, arrhythmias, MI, and Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy as it decreases heart rate, conduction, and contraction. But it is contraindicated in sick sinus syndrome. Acute intravenous use to convert PSVT and for rate control in AF • Chronic treatment to prevent PSVT and control rate in AF Hypertension Angina Rate control in atrial fibrillation

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: C. PSVT is a type of supraventricular tachycardia named for its intermittent abrupt onset and termination episodes. Often people have no symptoms. Otherwise, symptoms may include palpitations, increased heart rate, lightheadedness, sweating, shortness of breath, and chest pain. Option: D. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is when the heart thickens without an obvious cause. The parts of the heart most commonly affected are the interventricular septum and the ventricles. This results in the heart being less able to pump blood effectively

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman admitted to the emergency department with a myocardial infarction developed sustained ventricular tachycardia. Neither amiodarone nor lidocaine was effective, and the cardiologist decided to try another drug that acts mainly by blocking activated Na+ channels and K+ channels. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Procainamide

Highyeild:

Reason- Procainamide is a class Ia antiarrhythmic drug. All drugs of this class block activated sodium and potassium channels. Amiodarone and lidocaine are the drugs of choice for treating ventricular arrhythmias in the peri-infarction period. Procainamide is an alternative agent when the abovementioned drugs are either not tolerated or ineffective. The drug blocks activated Na+ channels, and recovery from blockade is about 1.8 seconds (the fastest of class Ia drugs), so it exerts a greater effect in depolarized and/or rapidly driven cardiac myocytes.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Mexiletin e is a class of Ib antiarrhythmic drugs that block fast sodium channels and reduce the action potential's phase 0 maximal upstroke velocity. Option: B. Adenosine miscellaneous antiarrhythmic drug acts on receptors in cardiac AV node- slowing conduction time. Option: C. Sotalol is classified as a class III antiarrhythmic, although it also possesses beta-blocking (class II) activity. Only it's class III effect modifies the cardiac myocyte action potential. Class III antiarrhythmics block the potassium channels in cardiac myocytes, increasing the effective refractory period.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, when returning from the market, feels his chest begins to hurt. The pain does not bother him too much, so he finishes his work and lies down to rest. The pain stops, so he disregards the episode entirely until the next day when he experiences a "funny feeling in his chest" and goes to the doctor at his wife's request. An ECG reveals atrial flutter, for which the doctor prescribes sotalol. The intended effect of sotalol involves modifying which phase of the cardiac myocyte action potential?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phase 3

Highyeild:

Reason- Phase 3. Sotalol is classified as a class III antiarrhythmic but also possesses beta-blocking (class II) activity. Only it's class III effect modifies the cardiac myocyte action potential. Class III antiarrhythmics block the potassium channels in cardiac myocytes, increasing the effective refractory period. Although potassium initially begins to flow out of the cell during phases 1 and 2, phase 3 is dominated by potassium efflux and undergoes the greatest change with sotalol. Prolonging phase 3 is the intended effect of sotalol.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Phase 0 corresponds to the influx of sodium ions, depolarizing the cell. Class I antiarrhythmics modify this phase by blocking sodium entry. Option: B. Phase 1 corresponds to the initial potassium outflow before the phase 2 plateau. Modifying phase 1 is not the intent of sotalol administration. Option: C. Phase 2 corresponds to an efflux of potassium, balancing an influx of calcium, causing a plateau in the action potential. Modifying phase 2 is not the intent of the sotalol administration.
